fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let E \subset \mathbb {R}^d be a measurable set and p \in [1, +\infty ]. We call \mathcal {L}^p(E) the set of measurable functions f: E \to \mathbb {R} such that
Now, we set the following equivalence relation on \mathcal {L}^p(E). Let f,g \in \mathcal {L}^p(E). We say that f \sim g if f(x) = g(x) for almost every x \in E. We set
i.e. L^p(E) is the quotient (vector) space of \mathcal {L}^p(E) through the relation \sim
For a given equivalence class [f] \in L^p(E), we define the norm of [f] as ||f||_{L^p(E)} for an arbitrary representative f \in [f].
From now on, by abuse of notation, we shall confuse [f] and its representative f. The space L^p(E) is the L^p space on E.
Note: The elements of L^p spaces are not individual functions in the strictest sense, but rather equivalence classes of functions.
the following limit holds in L^2(\Omega )
The concept of "almost surely" in probability theory is precisely the probabilistic analogue of "almost everywhere" (a.e.) in measure theory and functional analysis.
Measure Theory/Functional Analysis ("Almost Everywhere"):

In measure theory, "almost everywhere" means that a property holds true for all points in a set, except possibly for a set of measure zero. For example, if a function is continuous almost everywhere, it means the set of points where it is discontinuous has Lebesgue measure zero. This concept is fundamental for defining integrals (e.g., Lebesgue integral) and understanding properties of functions in L^p spaces.
Probability Theory ("Almost Surely"):
Probability theory is built on measure theory. A probability space is a special kind of measure space where the total measure is 1.
In this context, "measure zero" in general measure theory corresponds to "probability zero" in probability theory.
Therefore, an event occurring "almost surely" means that the set of outcomes where the event does not occur has probability zero.
An equivalence relation on a set X is a binary relation, often denoted by \sim , that is:

fr:ul.fr:li: Reflexive: x \sim x for all x \in X
Symmetric: If x \sim y, then y \sim x for all x, y \in X
Transitive: If x \sim y and y \sim z, then x \sim z for all x, y, z \in X

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An equivalence relation partitions a set into disjoint equivalence classes, where each equivalence class consists of all elements that are equivalent to each other under the relation.

In the context of Lp spaces, an important equivalence relation is defined by declaring two functions equivalent if they are equal almost everywhere (i.e., they differ only on a set of measure zero). This allows us to treat functions that are essentially the same (from an integration perspective) as a single entity in L^p spaces.
Common examples of equivalence relations include:

fr:ul.fr:li: Equality (=) on any set
Congruence modulo n on integers: a \equiv b \pmod {n} if and only if a - b is divisible by n
Similarity of matrices: Two matrices A and B are similar if there exists an invertible matrix P such that B = P^{-1}AP
Equality almost everywhere for measurable functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A property is said to hold almost everywhere (abbreviated as "a.e.") on a measure space (X, \mathcal {A}, \mu ) if the set of points where the property fails has measure zero.
Formally, a property P holds almost everywhere if there exists a measurable set N with μ(N) = 0 such that P holds for all x \in X \setminus N.
This concept is fundamental in measure theory and functional analysis because it allows us to ignore sets of measure zero, which are often irrelevant for integration and other analytical purposes.
For example, two measurable functions f and g are said to be equal almost everywhere if \mu (\{x \in X : f(x) \neq g(x)\}) = 0.
An equivalence relation on a set X is a binary relation, often denoted by \sim , that is:

fr:ul.fr:li: Reflexive: x \sim x for all x \in X
Symmetric: If x \sim y, then y \sim x for all x, y \in X
Transitive: If x \sim y and y \sim z, then x \sim z for all x, y, z \in X

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An equivalence relation partitions a set into disjoint equivalence classes, where each equivalence class consists of all elements that are equivalent to each other under the relation.

In the context of Lp spaces, an important equivalence relation is defined by declaring two functions equivalent if they are equal almost everywhere (i.e., they differ only on a set of measure zero). This allows us to treat functions that are essentially the same (from an integration perspective) as a single entity in L^p spaces.
Common examples of equivalence relations include:

fr:ul.fr:li: Equality (=) on any set
Congruence modulo n on integers: a \equiv b \pmod {n} if and only if a - b is divisible by n
Similarity of matrices: Two matrices A and B are similar if there exists an invertible matrix P such that B = P^{-1}AP
Equality almost everywhere for measurable functions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A set E in a measure space (X, \mathcal {A}, \mu ) is said to be measurable if it belongs to the σ-algebra \mathcal {A}.

In the context of Lebesgue measure on \mathbb {R}^d, a set is Lebesgue measurable if it belongs to the Lebesgue σ-algebra, which is the σ-algebra generated by all open (or equivalently, closed) subsets of \mathbb {R}^d.
Alternatively, a set E is Lebesgue measurable if for every ε > 0, there exists an open set G containing E such that the Lebesgue outer measure of G \setminus E is less than ε.

A norm on a vector space V is a function ||\cdot ||: V \rightarrow \mathbb {R} that assigns a non-negative real number to each vector in the space, satisfying the following axioms for all vectors u, v \in V and scalars a:

fr:ul.fr:li: Non-negativity: ||v|| \geq 0, and ||v|| = 0 if and only if v = 0

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A norm generalizes the intuitive notion of length or magnitude to abstract vector spaces. It induces a metric d(u,v) = ||u-v|| on the vector space, making it a metric space.
Common examples of norms include:

fr:ul.fr:li: The Euclidean norm on \mathbb {R}^n: ||x||_2 = \sqrt {x_1^2 + x_2^2 + \cdots + x_n^2}
The p-norm on \mathbb {R}^n: ||x||_p = \left ( |x_1|^p + |x_2|^p + \cdots + |x_n|^p \right )^{1/p} for p \geq 1
The maximum norm on \mathbb {R}^n: ||x||_\infty = \max \{|x_1|, |x_2|, \ldots , |x_n|\}
The sup norm on function spaces: ||f||_\infty = \sup _{x} |f(x)|
The L^p norm on function spaces: ||f||_p = \left (\int |f(x)|^p dx\right )^{1/p} for p \geq 1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In functional analysis, a "space" typically refers to a vector space equipped with additional structure, such as a topology, norm, or inner product. These structures provide a framework for studying functions as vectors and for analyzing limiting operations.
Common types of spaces in functional analysis include:

fr:ul.fr:li: Vector spaces: Sets equipped with operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication that satisfy certain axioms
Metric spaces: Sets equipped with a distance function (metric) that defines the concept of nearness between elements
Normed spaces: Vector spaces equipped with a norm function that assigns a notion of length to vectors
Banach spaces: Complete normed vector spaces, where every Cauchy sequence converges
Inner product spaces: Vector spaces equipped with an inner product, which generalizes the dot product in Euclidean space
Hilbert spaces: Complete inner product spaces, combining the structures of Banach spaces and inner product spaces
Topological vector spaces: Vector spaces equipped with a topology compatible with the vector operations
Locally convex spaces: Topological vector spaces where the topology is defined by a family of seminorms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Function spaces are particularly important in functional analysis. These are spaces whose elements are functions, such as:

fr:ul.fr:li: C(X): The space of continuous functions on a topological space X
L^p: The spaces of measurable functions whose p-th power is integrable
H^k: Sobolev spaces of functions with weak derivatives up to order k

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The study of these spaces and the operators between them forms the core of functional analysis.
